Column Comment.0: SEISMIC PATCH: This table is used to capture generalized recording patch designs.Details about the patch design are contained in the table SEIS_PATCH_DESC or asa digital file that is stored in the RM module. .
Column Comment.1: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.2: CHANNEL COUNT: the number of channels that are recorded in this patch.
Column Comment.3: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that the data in this row first came into effect.
Column Comment.4: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the data in this row was no longer active or in effect.
Column Comment.5: GAP COUNT: the number of stations that are in the gap in proximity to the seismicsource. There can be zero channels in the gap or the number of receiver stations thatare inactive during a shot.
Column Comment.6: PATCH LAYOUT: textual description of the patch layout, such as2000-100-0-100-2000.
Column Comment.7: PATCH TYPE: The type of seismic patch that was used in recording, such as splitspread, end-on, grid etc.
Column Comment.8: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.9: REMARK: Narrative remarks relating to this row of data.
Column Comment.10: ROLL ALONG METHOD: for seismic data, the type of roll along used for fieldrecording. May be 4 station switch, fixed for patch, fixed for seis set etc.
Column Comment.11: SHOT GAP INDICATOR: A Y / N flag indicating whether there is a shot gap presentin this patch design.
Column Comment.12: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.13: SYMMETRIC INDICATOR: A Y / N flag indicating whether this patch is designed sothat the receiver stations are positioned symmetrically around the shot position.Usually relevent for conventional 2D data, where the geophones are placed so thatthe shot is halfway down the spread.
Column Comment.14: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.15: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.16: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.17: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.18: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.19: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.20: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
